description: Intensive exposure to current issues and solutions in contemporary human interactions with the environment. Global in scope, but focused on case histories. Emphasis on providing biological and sociological background for a given major environment-human interaction, and state-of-the-art suggested solutions.
name: HUMANS & THE ENVIRONMENT

values.comments:
This course explores the interface of contemporary humans with their
environments across the world by focusing on various case histories, with a strong
emphasis on biology. Lectures are recorded and based on photographic essays mounted
onto Power Point presentations, often containing over 50 images with accompanying text.
Several classes are taught by guest lecturers. The textbook used is The Diversity of Life,
by Wilson (1999). The course fulfills the Natural Science and Mathematics sector
requirement and is not recommended for freshman or students without some background
in biology.
Many students referred to this course as “the best class” they have ever taken,
reporting “the material was really interesting, even for people who don’t have much
interest in biology.” There was a lot of material to be learned, however.
Nearly every student gave Professor Janzen fantastic reviews, describing him as
“an icon in science… an inspiration to anyone interested in biology.” He was noted for
his “extensive life experiences” in the subject and the fact that he “discovered a lot” of
what was studied in class. Students reported Professor Janzen had the ability to make
“ecology extremely interesting and accessible.”
Both science and non-science majors really enjoyed this class and found it
manageable. The course does require “a lot of reading,” but not much work outside of
that. Additionally, the material was described as “not difficult.” Students described the
exams as “fair,” but they could be very “specific.”
